content:
âœ… Approved the contribution.
Comment: Like I said before, this puzzle will showcase different coding techniques which I believe is extremely beneficial to all of us.

âœ… Approved the contribution.
Comment: The designer took the comments into account. This contribution will be a very good training in the easy category

âœ… Approved the contribution.
Comment: Good.  The real life situation is easy to imagine.  
This stretched me to solve it, and I like that !

I am giving it approval, but have one more tiny suggestion:

Suggest changing 
"a summary of all the construction sites encountered"
to 
"a summary of each construction site encountered"

Hey CodinGamer! Your contribution has unfortunately not been moderated on time and will temporarily be removed from the system... But no worries! You can republish it anytime to give it another chance! :)
Really nice

I also like this challenge.
But like Lisa-Has-Ideas and Timinator I think "yard" is not very clear, I prefer the term "section" (moreover you use this term in the description)

The inputs could be something like this:
Line 1: An integer roadLength for the total kilometers of the route
Line 2: An integer sectionQuantity for the number of road construction sites
Next sectionQuantity lines: Two space separated integers sectionStart and sectionSpeed, respectively for the kilometer in which the road construction site begins, and the relative speed limit in km/h

I like this, and solving it was a pleasure and a challenge.

I am ready to give it an "Approval" if you will address a few phrasing issues:
~change "the generic limit" to "the standard limit" or "the normal limit" or something like that.  "Generic" just doesn't seem like the right term here.
~"yard" (as in "yardQuantity" and "yardKm" and "yardSpeed") does not seem like the right term.  In USA, we might say "Stretch of Road" or "Section of Road" or "Strip of Road".  Please consider rephrasing that, because "yard" (at least for Americans) is a confusing term, as Timinator has said also

I was confused by the terms "yardQuantity", "yardKm" and "yardSpeed".  In America, the construction yard is the area where the construction crew keeps their materials.  The stretch of road under construction is referred to as a construction zone or a construction site.  Since you use the term "construction site" several time, I'd like to see the variable names changed to "siteQuantity", "siteKm" and "siteSpeed" or "zoneQuantity", "zoneKm" and "zoneSpeed".  (By the way...I did confirm this with my Civil Engineer long-time construction buddy.)

I think this puzzle is easy enough to be a Clash of Code.  However, I also believe the possible solutions will provide a wonderful comparison of straightforward approaches vs. modern "Pythonic" approaches and seeing these style differences is one of the things I find most powerful about easy puzzles.

Other than my hang-up on the variable names, I am ready to approve.

"It must be rounded up to the nearest minutes (as integer)" should be 
"It must be rounded to the nearest minute (as integer)".
No love for road construction and all the wasted time? :(

Input section
* Please state the measurement unit of yardSpeed.

Output section
* Suggest to change "provided in" to "rounded up to the nearest" for clarity.

Constraints section
* In some cases yardSpeed is 130, which violates the constraint "0 < yardSpeed < 130". Please fix either the cases or the constraint.

Cases
* The last pair of test and validator are the same. Please revise them so that they are similar but different.

Thanks.
P.S.: I created this Puzzle as a reminder of a bad trip from France to Italy, in which I spent more time on the road construction sites than on the normal motorway

Haha ! French roads !
I'm also confused by the terms "yard*".
I immediately thought of unit conversions (since the yard is an American unit), luckily that's not it.
An other issue is that as currently presented, Mario will never regain a speed of 130 km/h (far too realistic ðŸ˜‰).
I think you have two possibilities :
  - use "zones":
    - ensure that the first one starts at 0 km
    - allow a zoneSpeed of 130 km/h
  - use "sites":
    - add a siteLength parameter
    - then if Mario is not on a site, he can go to 130km/h

I think that the 'zone' option is the closest to your initial thoughts (since solutions are compatibles).

Thanks for the advice, I followed them all!

As for the cases, now â€œCÃ´te d'Azurâ€ contains the same speed limit for several adjacent road construction sites. Not really an edge case, but I think it's interesting nonetheless: optimizations could be considered.
Thanks for the advice, fixed!
Thanks for the advices! In the end I decided for "zone"
Thanks for the advices! Yes, I went with "zone", but I've also replaced "generic" with "standard".
Thanks for the advices! I went with â€œzoneâ€, I hope it will be clearer than yard anyway.
Let's try again, then!
Thanks for your advice, I've fixed it :)
Thank you so much, I hope it will be fun for whoever tries it! :)
Thank you so much, I hope it will be fun for whoever tries it! :)
Thank you so much, I hope it will be fun for whoever tries it! :)

Thank you.

"Genova - Roma" test and validator are still the same. Please revise them so that they are similar but different.
Ah, I misunderstood your previous comment. Done, thanks again!

Thanks for the advices!
For this round, so a puzzle of level "easy", I'm just giving for granted that the speed changes are instantaneous.
Maybe there will be in the future some â€œANOTHER ROAD CONSTRUCTION SITE - Nâ€ in which we will take care of the accelerating/decelerating partsâ€¦. and other ideas that I may have in mind!
